FacilityName: NEW COOPERATIVE INC. RANDS NURSE TANKS
SafetyInspectionBy: IA Dept of AG & Land Stewardship

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building,electrical  and plumbing codes; plus the Iowa Fertilizer Laws
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism (methamphetamines) NEW Cooperative, Inc. has installed concrete blocks two foot by two foot by six feet around the perimeter of the pump assembly to prevent vehicular damage to them.
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Flow Limiters=what in the trade is called an excess flow valve
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspections / routine preventive maintenance & repairs.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: EMERGENCY SHUT OFF VALVE, LIQUID PUMP, PIPING, AND POP OFF VALVES.
_prev_prog_2.Description: This plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before  they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system that may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before  they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. (This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire.) Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT NEW COOPERATIVE, INC., RANDS, IOWA

This facility complies with ANSI Standard k-61.1-1995 requirements for Anhydrous Ammonia storage. It is our policy to adhear to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately vacate the premises, move to a safe location, and notify the Lohrville Volunteer Fire Department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Region 5 LEPC will be made.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned. In that event, what we may have planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certian procedures that are intended to minimize the hazzards assiciated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.

The primary emergency response coordinator for the Lohrville, Iowa location is Don Stelling, location manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. The 24-hour emergency response number provided in that section also provides a telephone tree for additional individuals who are available and can respond to an emergency at that location.

DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT NEW COOPERATIVE, INC. RANDS/ROCKWELL CITY, IOWA.

This facility is a parking lot staging area for nurse tanks. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this

facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.

Nures tanks are filled and positioned awaiting distribution and transportion from the parking to the farm. In this instance, nurse tanks are parked in a lot that is not situated on continguous property to the bulk plant. At any one point in time between 1-20 nurse tanks could be parked in this lot awating pickup or delivery to area crop producers. The specific address of the parking lot is described in the registration section of this document.

THE WORSE-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO:

The worse-case senario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammomia vapor cloud) form. According to EPA's RMP* Comp (Version 1.06. The alternative release scenarion involves the transport delivery vehicle pulling away from the intake lines into the storage plant without disconnecting the transfer hoses. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard k-61.1-1995 and State Law.

In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, NEW Cooperative, Inc. has extended to the LOHRVILLE Volunteer Fire Department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.

FIVE- YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

NEW Cooperative, Inc. Rands, Iowa has never had an accident involving a

nhydrous ammonia that causde death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings in place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia systen, it is the policy of NEW Cooperative, Inc. to immediately notify the Lohrville Volunteer Fire Department and the Region 5 LEPC to request that they respond to the emergency. In the unlikely event that the Lohrville Volunteer Department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at our Rands location, mutual aid (reciprocal agreement between neighboring fire departments) will be summoned. We have discussed this policy with the fire department and Region 5 LEPC. Members of the fire department and the LEPC have inspected our anhydrous plant. In addition, copies of photographs taken of our plant have been provided (for reference) to both entities.

PLANNED CHANGES TO INPROVE SAFETY:

None
